conclusion: Identify the given values: Mass of body A, Mass of body B, Radius of all bodies, Coefficient of kinetic friction, Gravitational acceleration
Calculate the normal force F exerted by the ground on body A: F = m * 9.8
Calculate the frictional force f exerted on body C: f = (sqrt(3)/6) * m * 9.8
Since the bodies are in equilibrium, the sum of the normal forces on both A and B must equal the sum of the frictional forces on both A and B.
Calculate the total normal force F_A on body A: F_A = m * 9.8
Calculate the total frictional force f_A on body A: f_A = (sqrt(3)/6) * m * 9.8
Since the bodies are in equilibrium, set F_A = f_A: m * 9.8 = (sqrt(3)/6) * m * 9.8
Calculate the magnitude of the normal force F on body A: F = (9.8 * 6)/sqrt(3) * 9.8
Calculate the magnitude of the frictional force f on body C: f = (sqrt(3)/6) * m * 9.8
Since the bodies are in equilibrium, the frictional force f on body C is equal to the normal force F on body A.
Substitute the value of m to find the final magnitude of the normal force F: F = (9.8 * 6)/sqrt(3) * 9.8
Calculate the final answer for normal force: F = 9.8 * 9.8
The final answer for normal force is: F = 98 N
The frictional force f on body C is: f = (sqrt(3)/6) * m * 9.8
Since the bodies are in equilibrium, the frictional force f on body C is equal to the normal force F on body A.
Substitute the value of m to find the final magnitude of the frictional force f: f = (sqrt(3)/6) * m * 9.8
The final answer for frictional force is: f = 98 N
